p: In AlZnMg(Cu) alloys, quench-induced precipitates of the Î·-Mg(Zn,Al,Cu) 2 phase can be considered the most detrimental precipitation in terms of quench sensitivity, since this phase forms at relatively fast cooling rates while its precipitates barely have a hardening effect. Quench-induced phases at even lower temperatures, namely thin Y-phase platelets [ 119, 143, 198] and clusters [ 102, 103, 104], may form during even faster cooling. These quench-induced precipitates are small enough to cause a significant hardening effect [ 143].
